Dear Ms. Lawson:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 1/22/2025. An Exit conference was held with the agency onsite on 1/23/2025 Due to
the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 899-7818.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record must contain all the following
information before employment may occur:
(d) Three references obtained from persons who are
unrelated to the staff person.
One of 11 new employee records reviewed showed two of the employee's three
references were received after the employee's 8/12/2024 date of hire.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record must contain all the following
information before employment may occur:
(h) Documentation from the department that the person
has not been named in a central registry case as the
perpetrator of child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in
any state where the person lived in the 5 years
preceding hire.
One of 11 new employee records reviewed did not show documentation of a
children protective services clearance for the employee from the state of Alaska,
where the employee had resided within five years prior to her 10/21/2024 date of
hire. The clearance was completed on 12/16/2024.

CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record must contain both of the
following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's
performance within a probationary period or not later
than 6 months after the staff member assumes his or
her current responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a
written evaluation must be conducted every 12 months.
Two of 21 employee records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record showed the employee’s annual evaluation due by 2/26/2024
was completed late on 3/15/2024.
• A second record showed the employee’s annual evaluation due by
2/19/2024 was completed late on 3/15/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(i) A comprehensive medical examination, including a
behavioral/mental health and trauma screening, within
30 calendar days from the date the child entered into
an out-of-home placement, regardless of the date of
the last physical examination.
Three of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record showed the child's medical exam due by 1/29/2024 was
completed late on 2/6/2024.
• A second record showed the child's medical exam due by 10/5/2024 was
completed late on 10/22/2024. This youth's trauma screening due by
10/5/2024 was not documented.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal Inspection 2023, CAP approved 2/24/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:

(e) A dental examination must be completed within 3
months before entry into foster care or an initial dental
examination must be completed not more than 90
calendar days after entry into a foster care out-of-home
placement. A child entering foster care under 1 year of
age must have an initial dental exam within 3 months of
his or her first birthday.
Two of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record did not show documentation of the child's dental exam due by
8/18/2024, which was three months following the child's first birthday.
• A second record showed the child's dental due by 4/28/2024 was
completed late on 6/6/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal
and at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the child's 7/3/2024-
9/30/2024 updated service plan (USP) was completed 7 days late on 10/8/2024.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2023, CAP approved 2/24/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents
and the foster parents in the development of service
plans to enable the parent or parents and foster
parents to understand the plan for the child and the
parents' and the foster parent's role in assisting the
agency in carrying out the plan. An agency shall give a
copy to and review the parent-agency treatment plan
with the parent or parents and foster parents. The
agency must inform the parent or parents and foster
parent that the information in the parent-agency
treatment plan and any other information about the
child and the child's family is confidential.
Two of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:

• One record showed the child's 12/6/2023-1/4/2024 initial service plan (ISP)
was not signed by the caregiver or birth mother. Nor was the child's 4/4/24-
7/2/2024 USP signed by the birth mother.
• A second record showed the child’s 1/18/24-4/16/24 USP was not signed
by youth until 6/20/24
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim Inspection 2024, cited under FOM 722-8D, CAP approved 4/19/2024
Renewal Inspection 2023, cited under ISEP 6.19(5)(c) & FOM 722-8D, CAP
approved 2/24/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(a), must include all the following
information:
(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as
required under R 400.12404(4).
Five of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the child’s initial service
plan did not show documentation of (c) as required by the rule. The information
was either left blank or not shown.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal Inspection 2023, CAP approved 2/24/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact
(4) An agency shall facilitate in-person contact between
siblings who are not placed together except when there
is a court determination that contact is detrimental to
either child.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed where siblings were split did not
show documentation of a December 2024 sibling visit.
CPA Rule 400.12504 Eligibility requirements.
(2) All the following must be in the case record before a
youth is placed in independent living:
(f) Proof that financial support to meet the youth's
housing, clothing, food, and miscellaneous expenses is
available.

Two of three open independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation of (f) as required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12604 Orientation.
(1) An agency shall provide an orientation for
prospective applicants for adoption before an adoptive
application is provided.
Four of seven adoptive family records reviewed showed the family signed/ was
provided an application prior to their orientation date.
CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a
written adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family
signing an adoption application and prior to approving a
family for adoption.
Five of seven adoptive family records reviewed showed the family's adoptive
evaluation was not completed within 90 days of the family's application date.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R400.12604(1) Orientation
• The agency was apprised it shall clearly show proof that each applicant was
provided orientation.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R400.12306(3) Application request
• The agency was advised that including the wording that the application is
enclosed onto the letter it sends foster parents related to their upcoming renewal
inspection may aid it showing clear and consistent compliance with the rule.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.

There were two incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period:
The first incident related to an allegation that the foster parents were hitting the
child, and the child had bruises on her knees. During the special evaluation the
child and foster parents denied the allegations. The child reported getting the
bruising to her knees while playing and falling down. The foster parent was found in
noncompliance with the foster home behavior management rule because during the
investigation the foster father reported that he has pinched the child in the past
when she has gotten out of her car seat when he was driving. A corrective action
plan was completed with the foster parents around them taking training on the use
of nonphysical discipline, them explaining what they learned and what they will do
differently.
The second incident related to an allegation that the foster parent sprays the foster
child with a squirt bottle, as discipline when the child lies. During the special evaluation
the foster mother and child reported the foster mother sprayed the child with water
from a squirt bottle for lying about getting in trouble in school. The foster mother
admitted to spraying the child twice. The foster home was found in violation of the
foster home behavior management rule. A corrective action plan was completed with
the foster parents that included a review of trauma assessments, discussion with the
foster parentsaround proper forms of discipline and on behavior expectations;
discipline strategies; utilizing available supports, such as the parents calling agency
staff and other care providers for support.
The agency appeared to have acted appropriately related to both special
evaluations and it adhered to departmental timeframes and requirements related to
these special evaluations.

Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans during this
licensing period:
The first corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2024 Interim inspection
where it received 6 rule violations.
During this current inspection for the agency’s renewal license, the agency
received 12 rule violations. This number is an increase from the agency’s 2024
inspection. Of the 12 citations, 4 are repeat violations within the last two years.
Only 1 is a specific repeat violation from the inspection in 2024. The agency’s
corrective action plan compliance around this 1 rule violation, is as follows: the
number of individual cases cited deceased from 4 of 8 to 2 of 8.
Notwithstanding the increase in citations this inspection, this inspection’s review
showed a very low number of repeat violations. The agency has implemented and
is adhering to its interim inspection corrective action plan. The agency reported it
is focusing on its key performance indicators (KPI) and it continues its efforts to
improve compliance with all rules and policies.
The second corrective action plan related to Special Investigation
2024SIC0001508, related to a complaint received on 6/13/2024. The complaint
alleged that in April 2023, the agency completed a special evaluation on a foster
home and established willful and substantial violations yet recommended a
corrective action plan. The special investigation found the agency in violation of
rule R 400.14325 (1) An agency shall recommend to the department the
appropriate licensing action consistent with facts contained in the foster home
evaluation and any special evaluations. An acceptable corrective action plan was
submitted, that indicated team training on the process of special evaluations; that
during the special evaluation/prior to its completion, a meeting will occur with staff
associated with the foster home to review the findings of the special evaluation,
and the foster home’s current licensing characteristics; and that the agency would
make an assessment to determine if any characteristics or licensing modification
are needed.
The agency has implemented its corrective plan related to the stated special
investigation and are in compliance with it.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency submitted a chief administrator’s report dated 12/2/2024. The chief
administrator’s report indicated the agency has found improvements in all the
areas it was found in noncompliance at the last inspection. The agency attributed
this improvement to their tracking systems, reminders to staff of various due dates,

and use of DocuSign to obtain various needed signatures. Also as alluded to prior
in this report, the agency reported it has been focusing on its KPI areas. As it
relates to those KPI compliance areas, the agency has been in collaboration with
department so as to aid in perhaps seeing what they may be missing in some
compliance areas. The chief administrator/agency also reported that staff turnover
in foster care, adoption, licensing and clerical has impacted their compliance in
some areas. Other barriers the agency reported as impacting compliance included
delays in data entry from departmental staff in MISACWIS, delays in IV-E case
reads, delays by the department related to case assignments and permanent
warship status changes. The agency reported notwithstanding these issues they
continue their efforts to improve compliance and keep their staff informed.
Financial Overview
The agency provided a copy of its October 1, 2024, to September 30,2025 budget,
and its most recent independent financial audit for 9/30/2023. A review of these
documents did not indicate any concerns.
Staff Interviews
In addition to a discussion with agency's licensee designee and four other agency
administrative staff, a foster care supervisor, Licensing supervisor, licensing
worker, foster care worker, and adoption worker/foster worker were interviewed.
Staff interviewed reported the agency offers teamwork/team building; is supportive
to its staff; is responsive to staff, children, and family’s needs; child safety comes
first; all supervisors are available to any staff in times of need; and the agency is
organized and guided by policies. Matters reported as areas for continued growth
included: licensing staff and foster care staff maintaining communication with one
another; more DEI assistance; pay increases; continued facilitated times and
interactions between all program departments to enhance team work,
understanding of roles and communication; and advocating for more access to
resources for children and families.
Description of Agency Walk Through
Review of the agency's office space did not reveal any areas of concern related to
the space, equipment, or file storage.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety alerts this reporting period.

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
